channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: VX: The Nerve Agent Used To Kill Kim Jong Nam Is Rare And Deadly
item.description: February 24, 2017 - A colorless, odorless liquid, similar in consistency to motor oil, VX kills in tiny quantities that can be absorbed through the skin. It is among the deadliest chemical weapons ever devised.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - A colorless, odorless liquid, similar in consistency to motor oil, VX kills in tiny quantities that can be absorbed through the skin. It is among the deadliest chemical weapons ever devised. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/24/517053496/vx-the-nerve-agent-used-to-kill-kim-jong-nam-is-rare-and-deadly

item.title: Advice From Patients On A Study's Design Makes For Better Science
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Increasingly, advocates for patients are in the room when big medical studies are designed. They demand answers to big questions: "Will the results of this study actually help anybody?"
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Increasingly, advocates for patients are in the room when big medical studies are designed. They demand answers to big questions: "Will the results of this study actually help anybody?" http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/24/515226648/advice-from-patients-on-a-studys-design-makes-for-better-science

item.title: Mildred Dresselhaus, 'Queen Of Carbon' And Nanoscience Trailblazer, Dies At 86
item.description: February 24, 2017 - The daughter of poor immigrants, Dresselhaus became science royalty for her work with carbon materials. Along the way she opened opportunities for female scientists that didn't exist when she started.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - The daughter of poor immigrants, Dresselhaus became science royalty for her work with carbon materials. Along the way she opened opportunities for female scientists that didn't exist when she started. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/24/517004254/mildred-dresselhaus-queen-of-carbon-and-nanoscience-trailblazer-dies-at-86

item.title: Eric Haseltine: Can The Past Guide Us To Future Scientific Breakthroughs?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Trained as a neuroscientist, Eric Haseltine always asks questions. He's identified four concepts that lead to scientific breakthrough. One of them: acknowledging we're not the center of the universe.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Trained as a neuroscientist, Eric Haseltine always asks questions. He's identified four concepts that lead to scientific breakthrough. One of them: acknowledging we're not the center of the universe. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516727050/eric-haseltine-can-the-past-guide-us-to-future-scientific-breakthroughs

item.title: Liz Coleman: How Do We Teach College Students To Ask Big Questions?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Former Bennington College President Liz Coleman believes higher education is overly-specialized & complacent. She says we need to encourage students to ask bigger questions and take more risks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Former Bennington College President Liz Coleman believes higher education is overly-specialized & complacent. She says we need to encourage students to ask bigger questions and take more risks. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516726045/liz-coleman-how-do-we-teach-college-students-to-ask-big-questions

item.title: Kevin Jones: Can Embracing Uncertainty Lead To Better Medicine?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Sometimes, doctors just don't have the answers. Surgeon Kevin Jones says having the humility to acknowledge this leads to better medicine.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Sometimes, doctors just don't have the answers. Surgeon Kevin Jones says having the humility to acknowledge this leads to better medicine. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516710048/kevin-jones-can-embracing-uncertainty-lead-to-better-medicine

item.title: Naomi Oreskes: Why Should We Believe In Science?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - In school, we're taught we should trust science because the scientific method leads to measurable results and hard facts. But Naomi Oreskes says the process of inquiry doesn't end there.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - In school, we're taught we should trust science because the scientific method leads to measurable results and hard facts. But Naomi Oreskes says the process of inquiry doesn't end there. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516709308/naomi-oreskes-why-should-we-believe-in-science

item.title: Michael Stevens: How Do You Find Smart Answers to Quirky Questions?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - When Michael Stevens is confronted with a quirky question, he responsibly searches for the answer and posts it to YouTube — inviting millions of people to follow his journey of discovery.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - When Michael Stevens is confronted with a quirky question, he responsibly searches for the answer and posts it to YouTube — inviting millions of people to follow his journey of discovery. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516704705/michael-stevens-how-do-you-find-smart-answers-to-quirky-questions

item.title: Could A Bumblebee Learn To Play Fetch? Probably
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Scientists found that bumblebees are nimble learners, especially when there's a sugary reward at the end. No wonder they're such good pollinators.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Scientists found that bumblebees are nimble learners, especially when there's a sugary reward at the end. No wonder they're such good pollinators. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/24/516532358/could-a-bumblebee-learn-to-play-fetch-probably

item.title: Chemical Weapon Found On Body Of North Korean Leader's Half-Brother
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Malaysian police said VX nerve agent — classified as a weapon of mass destruction — was found on Kim Jong Nam's body. South Korea says North Korea ordered the hit.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Malaysian police said VX nerve agent — classified as a weapon of mass destruction — was found on Kim Jong Nam's body. South Korea says North Korea ordered the hit. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/24/516978090/chemical-weapon-found-on-body-of-north-korean-leaders-half-brother

item.title: PHOTOS: The Final Hours Of A Dakota Access Pipeline Protest Camp
item.description: February 23, 2017 - On Thursday morning, law enforcement cleared out the Oceti Sakowin camp in North Dakota, ending a months-long protest against the completion of the nearby Dakota Access Pipeline.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - On Thursday morning, law enforcement cleared out the Oceti Sakowin camp in North Dakota, ending a months-long protest against the completion of the nearby Dakota Access Pipeline. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/516920484/photos-the-final-hours-of-a-dakota-access-pipeline-protest-camp

item.title: To Test Zika Vaccines, Scientists Need A New Outbreak
item.description: February 23, 2017 - It's a bit of a paradox, but researchers say they need Zika virus to re-emerge this year so they can test vaccines designed to defeat it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - It's a bit of a paradox, but researchers say they need Zika virus to re-emerge this year so they can test vaccines designed to defeat it. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/23/516822252/to-test-zika-vaccines-scientists-need-a-new-outbreak

item.title: SpaceX Cargo Craft Is Now In Space Station's Grip, One Day After Aborted Docking
item.description: February 23, 2017 - NASA had originally planned for the Dragon craft to reach the space station three days ago. It's carrying crew supplies and a range of scientific experiments.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - NASA had originally planned for the Dragon craft to reach the space station three days ago. It's carrying crew supplies and a range of scientific experiments. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/516802421/spacex-cargo-craft-is-now-in-space-stations-grip-one-day-after-aborted-docking

item.title: Poverty Plus A Poisonous Plant Blamed For Paralysis In Rural Africa
item.description: February 23, 2017 - Some African countries have long witnessed mysterious outbreaks of paralysis. Affected regions are poor and conflict-ridden, where people's main food is a bitter, poisonous variety of cassava.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - Some African countries have long witnessed mysterious outbreaks of paralysis. Affected regions are poor and conflict-ridden, where people's main food is a bitter, poisonous variety of cassava. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/23/515819034/poverty-plus-a-poisonous-plant-blamed-for-paralysis-in-rural-africa

item.title: Should Scientists March? U.S. Researchers Still Debating Pros And Cons
item.description: February 23, 2017 - A "March for Science" is set for April 22 in Washington, D.C., to show support for evidence-based public policy. But some worry the march will be seen as partisan, and may even undermine sound policy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - A "March for Science" is set for April 22 in Washington, D.C., to show support for evidence-based public policy. But some worry the march will be seen as partisan, and may even undermine sound policy. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/515584634/should-scientists-march-u-s-researchers-still-debating-pros-and-cons
